14.text: It is so good to have you here.

15.text: This is a community forum so we are going to involve you along the way.

21.text: None of this 10 minutes at the end business.

23.text: You are part of this conversation.

26.text: And I really do believe that events like this

29.text: are fundamental to shifting the stigma.

34.text: One in five of us in Australia in the past year

37.text: have taken time off work because of mental health challenges

41.text: Work is so vital isn't it? It's so crucial.

44.text: It's a big part of who we are.

46.text: We pour a lot of energy into it.

48.text: If we're lucky to have paid work, it helps pay for our rent, our mortgages.

53.text: Put food on the table. But it's also about giving us meaning and purpose in life.

60.text: It's vital. There is an expectation at work that somehow we're going to be

63.text: 100% on the game every working hour and that's just not realistic.

69.text: We're human! So when we're stressed or anxious

73.text: or depressed, work doesn't really feel like a safe or inclusive or welcoming environment.

80.text: So instead we worry about what our boss might think

84.text: if we did say that we're feeling unwell or not up to scratch.

89.text: We worry about losing our job.

91.text: We worry about not getting a promotion the next time we want to go for one.

97.text: And sometimes workplaces handle these things incredibly poorly and punitively.

102.text: Others are quite enlightened on it

104.text: and we're going to meet a couple of employers who've really walked this path

108.text: and thought carefully about how they engage with these themes at work.

112.text: And apparently there's now $200 million dollars spent on compensation claims

118.text: that are mental health related each year in Australia.

120.text: That's an extraordinary figure isn't it.

122.text: And it raises profound questions for me about

124.text: are we actually navigating mental health and mental illness in the workplace very well at all.

128.text: I suspect not if it's landing in a compensation claims process.

132.text: So let me welcome without further ado

135.text: our special guests on the panel today, please welcome

137.text: Dr Sam Harvey. He is a consultant psychiatrist.

143.text: And Associate Professor in workplace mental health at the University of New South Wales.

149.text: He's a research fellow at the Black Dog Institute

152.text: He helped establish the Mentally Healthy Workplace Alliance.

155.text: We have Rachel Clements, please come on out.

162.text: Rachel is working with workplaces all the time.

166.text: She's an organisational psychologist. She's Director of Psychological Services

170.text: at the Centre for Corporate Health and also Resilia.

173.text: And she specialises in helping individuals and organisations really increase their emotional resilience

180.text: and manage mental health issues in the workplace.

191.text: John is a partner in a major law firm in Sydney.

194.text: He's become a very effective, strong spokesperson

198.text: based on his own experience of mental illness

201.text: in his case, bipolar disorder. And he's a community presenter

206.text: So he's decided to really take it public,

209.text: his own experiences, and it's been a fantastic thing.

219.text: Manager of health and wellbeing at Optus. So a big corporation

226.text: Hey welcome. It's great to have you here.

229.text: John, let me start with you.

232.text: A partner in a law firm. I mean... for a start, law.

236.text: High pressure. A lot of bravado in that profession.

241.text: A lot of macho. How often do mental health conversations get had in the legal setting, traditionally?

247.text: They're starting to be had more often.

250.text: The conversations now are sort of wrapped up in part of our caring for people,

256.text: And it's just for my sort of experience,

261.text: what I found was that, if people - if you speak to people, people actually do care.

266.text: That's the sort of bottom line for me.

268.text: And also the younger generation are a lot more adept at having these conversations.

275.text: For us old fogies, over 50s, it is a bit difficult.

279.text: You know, I come from country Queensland. I grew up in the eighties in Queensland.

282.text: That was not a place where you spoke about a lot of things including mental health.

286.text: Take us back to when you really started having a problem.

291.text: When you realised in yourself that things were going astray.

295.text: At the end of 2007, I worked long hours and

299.text: did something for clients, a matter for clients. And that worked out really well.

304.text: But then I went home for Christmas and I wasn't feeling great.

308.text: I lived a sort of split life. My wife and children lived in the Blue Mountains

314.text: we thought that would be a good thing to do.

315.text: I had a flat in the city and I remember staying in there

319.text: for two weeks just staying in bed, crying, not eating

323.text: I'd go out, down to the local IGA, get a few bits now and again

328.text: but at night, and I didn't want to see anyone.

331.text: And um, I slept a lot, I cried a lot.

335.text: And then... that went on for a few months and then my wife

339.text: went on the Black Dog Institute website

342.text: and scored me, I think it was 32 out of 33 on the test for bipolar

346.text: and said 'you ought to do this' and I scored 33 out of 33.

351.text: So it was a combination of my wife and I working out what went on.

355.text: Let me come to Mark Jacobson in the audience.

359.text: With you is your partner Alex. Thanks so much for being here.

362.text:
- So Mark, you work with Sydney Water. 
- Yes.

366.text:
- And I bet you can relate somewhat to what 
- 100 per cent. Everything.

371.text: So take us back to why you're here today and why you've decided to speak about your experiences publicly.

382.text: Um, roughly probably 2012, I went to work one morning

388.text: and as the morning went on, what I know it as now as anxiety and panic

393.text: had set in that morning. And I had no idea what was going on.

398.text: I didn't know if I was dying or what was going on.

404.text: It was actually a manager of mine that approached me and asked if I was ok.

410.text: His wife is actually a psychologist and

413.text: he was quite understanding. He sort of calmed me down

417.text: and suggested that I seek help about it.

420.text: And we've landed you thick right in the middle of the most traumatic experience.

426.text: And we should just establish what is the work that you do. You're a hydrologist -

430.text: - Yeah, for Sydney Water I'm a hydrologist and I've been working as a hydrologist with Sydney Water for six years,

437.text: a little bit - six and a half years now.

442.text: So did the anxiety feel like, that day, that it came out of nowhere?

446.text: Yeah it did. And I'm a big coffee drinker and

449.text: it was that morning that it was coffee after coffee

452.text: and I later found out that that helped bring it on because

458.text: it hypes you up a bit.

459.text: But I wasn't sure what was going on, you know,

463.text: I couldn't stop pacing, I couldn't sit still.

467.text: I just... had no way out of it.

471.text: It was.... now I look back on it that my manager

474.text: sort of stopped me and calmed me down

476.text: and suggested I see a doctor.

478.text: Yeah, so that's an interesting conversation that they initiated with you.

483.text: Yep. Because I didn't know how to present to him.

486.text: I didn't want to be at work that morning, I didn't want to be around anyone.

491.text: All I wanted to do was just sit in bed and

494.text: not see anyone, lock myself away.

497.text: And try and figure out what was going on.

500.text: So I had no idea how so how I was sort of going to suggest that to him

506.text: so it was fantastic that he sort of spotted the signs

510.text: and suggested that I seek help and take the time that I needed

514.text: to sort myself out with that.

516.text: Cause it's just not the sort of conversation we're used to having

519.text:
with our supervisors or managers is it. 
- Not at all.

523.text: And Alex has been phenomenal, hasn't she?

532.text: I often said to her that, in the beginning,

535.text: if I didn't have her there to sort of guide me through,

538.text: I didn't know where I would be, and that was completely honest.

542.text: She was pivotal in helping me get back on my feet

545.text: and that was where I came across Mates in Construction.

550.text: And just wanted to get involved.

553.text:
- And talk about it publicly.
- Yeah.

555.text: Which is a whole other step to take isn't it.

557.text: So beyond that moment of anxiety

560.text: did you manage to work out the dimensions of what you were feeling?

564.text: Of what was going on for you?

565.text: Not at all. It was just sort of little darting thoughts that just snowball

569.text: and roll and roll and roll into something so big that you just can't control it.

573.text: And that was where I thought I just wanted to shelter away from everyone.

578.text: And that leads to other things. I was embarrassed about going

581.text: back to work because I wondered what people would think of me

584.text: and what was going on and what not.

589.text: So taking the first step in getting help was lifesaving.

593.text: And we'll talk a bit later about what your supervisor and your colleagues put in place.

597.text: If there are any experiences you'd like to share as we go

601.text: pop your hand up. Yes please.

604.text: Hi. My name is Lyndsay. I work for Corrective Services NSW.

609.text: I used to be a prison officer.

611.text: Tough work environment, tough work environment.

612.text: I've had depression and anxiety for a long time and I've

619.text: I had a... in the last 12 months it's escalated

622.text: and I've had two significant breakdowns at work.

625.text: And I've been on stress leave twice.

628.text: I went on a holiday to try and get away from it all to Thailand,

633.text: and when I come back I had a discussion with my senior director about it

638.text: saying, you know, 'I'm pretty well stuffed,

640.text: I'm pretty well going to jump off the cliff.'

645.text: It's interesting you took these feelings of  what was going on for you to your manager. How did that conversation go?

651.text: Initially I thought it was going quite good.

652.text: Unbeknownst to me, he was getting quite upset about it.

656.text: So what happened was... and I'm talking about senior staff here.

660.text: I raised this issue that I had major concerns about

663.text: the way I was being managed, and I wasn't coping, in September

667.text: and I took that all the way to Assistant Commissioner level

669.text: and I have yet to get a response.

671.text:
- Yeah.
- And that was in September.

675.text: My immediate manager was pushing buttons like you wouldn't believe

678.text: So didn't take your experience and think, well what role can I play to help you, necessarily.

684.text: He had a major - I see him as being a major catalyst.

687.text: By this stage I'd upped my Zoloft to about 800mg

690.text: - So what could - just to keep the conversation going,

694.text: and I really appreciate you sharing that experience

696.text: and it sounds like you're kind of in the thick of it -

698.text: but what would have made a difference

700.text: in that conversation that you had with your manager?

705.text: I think that's a really good anchor. Support.

708.text: Let me come to our panel.

709.text: Rachel and Sam, there's so many variables to this, aren't there?

712.text: Sam why do we find it such difficult terrain in the workplace, mental health?

719.text: What are the things that we can get confused about in terms of our dynamics, our self, at work?

725.text: I think it is, look - I think we increasingly understand

728.text: that it's more confusing than we at first realised.

731.text: And I think part of that is because where we began the conversation around work and health

738.text: was when they were simple problems like dust in the mine, or things like that.

742.text: And it was a nice simple thing. You measure how much dust there is, you get rid of the dust, people don't get sick.

747.text: And I think we tried to take that paradigm into mental health in the workplace

752.text: and I think that's got us into a muddle which I think we're now getting out of.

758.text: For most people, being at work is a really good thing for their mental health.

762.text: And we know if we look at what happens to people's mental health when they lose their job,

766.text: that shows just how important it is.

768.text: But I think because it has such a key role in ourselves

771.text: and our self identity and what we do with our waking hours,

773.text: if things aren't right there, then that can have a real impact on us

778.text: And I think increasingly we also realise that

781.text: if we want to pick up when people are becoming unwell,

785.text: the workplace is an ideal place to do that.

788.text: And I think we heard that from Mark's story.

790.text: You know what struck me is even though those stories

793.text: are sort of similar to a lot of other stories I hear from

798.text: what I think is surprising - particularly about the first two -

801.text: is how quickly people were able to get diagnoses and help.

805.text: And I appreciate at the time that wouldn't have felt fast,

808.text: that period of a few months,

810.text: but actually, we regularly in a clinical setting will see people that

813.text: have been unwell for much longer periods of time.

816.text: and haven't been able to link into help.

819.text: And I think you guys explained very well why

822.text: that is. Because the very symptoms you're having

824.text: make it hard to ask for help.

825.text:
- So that's when it takes other people.
- Yeah.

828.text: - And a workplace is a community of people, at it's best.

832.text: And we do a lot of work around mental health in the community

835.text: but I think actually the workplace is a really

838.text: untapped resource that we haven't utilised as a place

841.text: to try and reach out to people and to try and help people recover.

845.text: But I think we are beginning to do that much better now.

847.text: Isn't that a great way of thinking about the workplace?

850.text: As a resource for improving mental health.

857.text: Rachel, as you were listening to the stories so far,

861.text:
- you're working with employers, with managers
- yep

864.text: - with corporations, all sorts of workplaces in all sorts of professions.

869.text: I mean are there particular dynamics in a workplace

873.text: that you see over and over again

876.text:
- that if only they were tweaked, if only they were changed,
- Yeah

880.text: The outcomes could have been so different.

883.text: Yeah, and I think that points to that very critical role of

886.text: supportive leadership. And we know that a big aspect of our positive wellbeing

890.text: when we're at work and things are going well,

892.text: is very much contributed by our immediate leader or line manager's management style.

897.text: And they've gone away and done a lot of research and worked out

900.text: what is the biggest predictive factor of positive wellbeing in the workplace?

903.text: And the number one is supportive leadership.

906.text: And that goes to show in terms of that, if there was just that support

909.text: shown at that time, not only can supportive leadership

915.text: it can actually also really assist people in the recovery process.

919.text: And people will recover a lot faster if

921.text: they know they've got a supportive leader, and a supportive team

926.text:
- Sam.
- I was just going to add to that.

927.text: I think one of the things, there are some managers that are just,

931.text: that are naturally good at this type of thing.

933.text: And I think we heard an example of that in that story.

936.text: But not everyone is. And I think what we are beginning to learn

939.text: is that we can teach people a certain amount of skills

942.text: that gets them up to the required standard

945.text: where they're being a help not a hindrance.

948.text: I think most managers know what they would like to do.

951.text: I think it's more a question of confidence of having those really difficult conversations.

956.text: I think we've got evidence now that we can show that

959.text: But also I wonder whether as employers,

962.text: there's a fine line where you go, well, I don't want to intrude in someone's private matters.

967.text: Their mental health is surely their private affair.

972.text: What you don't want is your manager at work being

976.text: some lay therapist, who suddenly is asking you about other things.

981.text: I think the point is, there's a role that managers have in

984.text: being supportive, and that's a key part of a manager's role,

987.text: and I think part of what we need to teach managers

990.text: how to be a good manager, is how to know what their role is.

993.text: Yes because just to be devil's advocate, Rachel,

995.text:
we come to our workplaces with a history. 
- Of course.

998.text: Family trauma, maybe a history of anxiety,

1002.text: our individual coping styles, our individual resilience

1006.text: or not as the case may be.

1008.text: - Is it the responsibility of a workplace to engage with any of that?

1015.text: Well I think historically it was very much, 10 or 15 years ago,

1019.text: it was very separate. Work and personal life

1022.text: were completely separate. Whereas now it's not so.

1025.text: And we know now the work health and safety legislation

1027.text: that came into effect particularly around 2012

1030.text: and that goes to show, if you are observing that someone is not

1033.text: travelling so well, regardless of causation,

1036.text: doesn't matter. If someone's not travelling so well

1038.text: because of a work related issue, or if they're not travelling

1041.text: so well at work because of a personal issue,

1043.text: or if they're not traveling so well at work because of a pre-existing mental health condition,

1047.text: the legislation now is in place to say

1049.text: if you are observing someone's not traveling so well,

1052.text: you are under a legal obligation to 'asses the risk', which means

1056.text: go and initiate a conversation with someone about

1058.text: the cause, what's going on, how can we help,

1061.text: and how can we assist and support.

1063.text: And then be able to put in a management plan for them.

1066.text: So I think we've seen a shift in that space,

1069.text: particularly since that legislation came about,

1071.text: in employers being a lot more proactive because now there's legislation to support that.

1076.text: But I still do see a lot of anxiety in workplaces

1078.text: around having the conversation, and I do think it's

1081.text: often because, in a lot of jobs, managers are in that role of trouble-shooting

1086.text: problem solving, dealing with something, putting a plan in place

1090.text: and making it all ok again.

1091.text: And I think it managers go into conversations around

1094.text: wellbeing and mental health with that same perspective and mentality,

1098.text: of course they're going to be anxious.

1100.text: Because they don't have the answers, it's not their role to fix it.

1103.text: It's not their role to be able to be that person's main source of support.

1108.text:
- Megan from Optus, you're nodding your head at intervals here.
- I am.

1112.text: What would you like to pipe in about?

1114.text: Cause you're an organisation.... you run a healthy minds initiative

1118.text: inside Optus to really try and engage your workforce

1123.text: with a whole range of different questions about mental health at work.

1127.text: And when we started looking at this a couple of years ago

1130.text: we, like a lot of organisations, we realised

1132.text: we had to do something. But we didn't quite know what.

1138.text: And one of the things that very much came out early in our research was

1141.text: - Just, I'll pause on that. Why did you realise you had to do something?

1145.text:
- What was happening in your workplace?
- The community expects it.

1149.text: I mean there's a change in legislation, certainly,

1154.text: And I mean our employees come from the community.

1156.text: And so there's a lot of talk in the community about mental health.

1159.text: I mean obviously in a big corporation you know the tradition might be

1164.text:
- they give you a gym membership discount 
- and a flu shot.

1169.text:
- A flu shot. That's called health and wellbeing in the workplace. 
- Yes, it was.

1174.text: Why did you want to dig deeper?

1176.text: Well because there's more to life than that.

1179.text: And as those barriers between work and life break down

1186.text: of course you know work is impacting on people's personal life.

1189.text: So we shouldn't be surprised when the reverse happens.

1191.text: And this is what we need to deal with as an employer.

1194.text: We want to keep people, we want to keep good people,

1197.text: and mental health issues were getting in the way of that because

1201.text: nobody quite knew what to do about it.

1203.text: And the leadership conversations were the things that came up as most important.

1207.text: And  as Sam said, leaders, managers, they want to do the right thing.

1210.text: They want to be supportive, but often are terrified.

1213.text: Don't want to make the situation worse.

1215.text:
- Sam. 
- Can I add one other dimension to it?

1218.text: And this might be a slightly unfair question Megan.

1220.text: But there's the legal responsibility, and there's the ethical wanting to do the right thing.

1224.text: I assume within an organisation increasingly there's also

1227.text: a financial imperative to do this because it just makes

1229.text: good economic sense to stop people getting unwell.

1232.text: And to minimise the harm when they get unwell.

1238.text: Because in the past people have just gone off on sick leave

1241.text: for months and months. And then somebody says,

1243.text: 'Oh, I wonder what's going on there?'

1246.text: And it's too late often then.

1247.text: And then... or it comes up in a performance management discussion.

1250.text: And sometimes that can be too late too.

1252.text: So what we want to do is to

1254.text: get discussions going around mental health

1259.text: Whether you're talking to a colleague

1261.text: or whether you're talking to someone who works in your team.

1263.text: So it comes up in a performance management discussion.

1265.text: I'll be really interested to hear if that's been your experience in a workplace.

1269.text: That somehow, you're experience of mental health or

1272.text: illness or ill health, has somehow got mixed up

1276.text: with the complications of performance management.

1279.text: Very delicate. I'll come to you in a tick.

1281.text: We've got Pam Rutledge who's actually

1283.text: from Richmond PRA. And they... you work with people

1288.text: who are having an enduring, chronic experience of

1291.text: mental illness, don't you? This is a kind of wrap-around service

1294.text: that supports them in all aspects of their life.

1299.text: The point I'd really like to pick up on

1301.text: however is as an employer, and we employ about 600 people,

1307.text: we are a mental health service organisation

1310.text: but we decided that, um, in that context

1315.text: with our focus on the value of lived experience,

1318.text: to inform and drive the work that we do,

1321.text: we needed to be an employer that walked the talk.

1325.text: And so we committed in 2012 to achieve a target

1330.text: of at least half of our workforce, our total workforce,

1335.text: being people who identify with a lived experience of mental health issue by 2017.

1340.text: And at the latest count we're at 49.2 [per cent].

1343.text: Can we just give them a round of applause please?

1350.text:
- It becomes part of the selection criteria.
- Yes it is.

1354.text: And we have an affirmative action approach so that we actually,

1357.text: where we have two people applying for any job in the organisation,

1361.text: and one of them is a person who identifies as having a lived experience,

1364.text: they get a preference under affirmative action policy.

1368.text: And so a lot of the conversation is about how to have that....

1373.text: how to be open about the conversation,

1377.text: about the fact that mental health issues

1379.text: do impact on the way we do our work,

1382.text: just as a family issue does, just as managing

1387.text: or working, having a sick child, or an ageing parent

1391.text: that we should be able to embrace in the workplace

1394.text: how we can have these open honest conversations.

1397.text: So our approach is to make it something

1401.text: that is talked about very early on,

1404.text: and so we encourage any of our employees to

1407.text: do with their manager a personal situation plan

1411.text: that identifies what might happen for them in the workplace,

1414.text: what their triggers might be, what things could occur

1419.text:
- that might make it difficult
- ok

1421.text: and so that means if something does happen,

1424.text: um the manager can have a conversation

1426.text: 'Hey I've noticed that...' or 'I'm observing that...'

1429.text: and, you know, we've got our plan, you know

1432.text: is it time to talk about how we can help you?

1435.text: And so we're trying to get the conversation

1437.text: happening in a really open way.

1440.text: And it's not perfect of course, we're not 100% there.

1444.text: But trying to turn it around so that it is

1447.text:
- part of normalised work experience. 
- Great, thanks Pam.

1451.text: I'll just come to.... we had another question here.

1453.text: Hello there, oh yes I know your face, hi.

1456.text: - You do. This isn't a question.

1459.text: My name is Judy, and I've had a lived experience of mental disorder for 50 years.

1466.text: I'm also a carer of two daughters who have mental disorder.

1475.text: and we've been trained by Schizophrenia Fellowship

1483.text: And I've been doing it now for about 15 to 16 years,

1488.text: where we go out into the workplace and share our experiences.

1494.text: So do you have a sense when you're in a workplace sharing your own story

1498.text:
- Do you have a sense of the impact of that?
- Oh I know very well.

1502.text:
- Tell us about the impact. 
- Well, ah,

1505.text: we were told at a conference last year by

1511.text: a psychiatrist from America who said,

1513.text: if you want to do anything to help mental health and mental awareness

1518.text: and reduce stigma, you just have to come out.

1521.text: And be prepared to share it and talk about it.

1526.text: And that way you get empathy and understanding from people.

1530.text:
- So...
- Can I say..
- Yes, Sam.

1532.text: And what you described fits with everything we're learning about

1538.text: how you reduce stigma. That you show people,

1541.text: you know you can show people as many powerpoint slides as you want explaining what depression is

1544.text: but it's only by getting people with that lived experience

1545.text: in the room, speaking with them, that that's what makes the difference.

1548.text: In the workplace, we did a thing with firefighters.

1551.text: These were big tough burly guys.

1552.text: And we said we were going to talk about how you have these difficult conversations.

1556.text: And one of the firefighters said to me, he said,

1559.text: 'Mate, you give me a burning building,

1562.text: I'd prefer to run into that than to have a conversation about mental health

1566.text: But um, you know we spent four hours with them,

1567.text: and it made a big difference. Six months later,

1572.text: reduction in sickness absence in the organisation.

1575.text: So it doesn't take much to change the dialogue.

1577.text: Yes so John, when you started to articulate what was going on for you,

1581.text: once you'd understood yourself what was going on,

1583.text: to your colleagues, to your partners in the law firm,

1586.text: to other colleagues, how did those conversations initially go?

1594.text: They range from, someone getting in the lift going, 'Hi are you ok?'

1597.text: 'Yeah.' 'Are you really ok? Are you really ok?

1600.text: Yeah I'm bipolar but don't worry about it.

1602.text: Or people, um, when you're a bit down and out

2683.text: for someone with a mental health issue,

2751.text: for that same journey. And the manager's just

3102.text: Yeah there's always a sweet irony, isn't there,

3105.text: that some of those professions, or departments or organisations that are

3109.text: actually focused on health outcomes are very poor at navigating their own challenges in the workforce.

3117.text: And to Mark. Any final comments from you

3120.text: on what one key shift would undermine this stigma that we experience?

3127.text: If you're an employer, or you're a manager in an organisation,

3131.text: you're not alone in trying to work out what you need to do.

3135.text: At a national level there's beyondblue Heads Up website and the Mentally Health Workplace Alliance

3140.text: that's got lots of resources written for employers.

3143.text: Within NSW we've got WayAhead and the Mental Health Promotion Network

3147.text: which has local meetings that will guide people

3150.text: who are new to this area to do stuff.

3152.text: If you're someone who's already suffering from a mental illness,

3154.text: and you're not doing... you're not getting the type of work you want at the moment,

3159.text: then tell your health professional that that needs to be part of your treatment plan.

3162.text: That that's part of your recovery.

3163.text: And if you're someone who has symptoms and is not getting help at the moment

3168.text: then ask for help, or use one of the online resources now

3171.text: if you're not ready to ask someone face to face.

3173.text: OK. Sharon Leadbeater from Wayahead, hello there.

3176.text: Let's just come briefly to you. What is Wayahead?

3180.text: What can you offer people in this audience?

3183.text: I work for Wayahead Mental Health Association which is

3184.text: a mental health promoting charity here in Sydney.

3187.text: I coordinate the workplace health program.

3190.text: And that is for any organisation that is interested in supporting the health and wellbeing of their employees.

3195.text: We provide network meetings for people, where we bring in

3198.text: expert guest speakers to present the latest

3201.text: best practice information, whether it's case studies or

3204.text: examples of research in the area, the latest findings.

3208.text: We also have a newsletter that goes out. We negotiate conference discounts

3212.text: for our members to try and help with their professional development.

3214.text: And we also have an extensive resources section because

3216.text: as the panel have pointed out tonight there's a lot more resources out there

3220.text: than they're ever used to be. And a lot aren't involving cost either.

3223.text: So we're trying to be a bit of a go-to hub.

3226.text: Any final comments, on stigma or otherwise. Rachel.

3229.text: I think it's around education, you know, it's around educating people

3234.text: and helping people feel a lot more confident

3236.text: and a lot more competent around having conversations with people about their wellbeing.

3242.text:
- Mark. 
- One of the biggest discoveries I've made

3247.text: since coming through it was, a little while back,

3249.text: I did a story with the Sydney Morning Herald

3253.text: involving Mates in Construction. One of the biggest

3255.text: discoveries I found after that story was just how many people are suffering as well.

3261.text: Who - you know, you'd never have any idea.

3264.text: And I think once people start to become more aware

3268.text: that anyone can be affected by it,

3270.text: I think it will be much more easier to talk about as well.

3278.text: If we go back and have a look at some things that

3281.text: we've done very well, how did we get fit?We told Norm to 'Life. Be in it.'

3287.text: How did we sort of draw attention to people with AIDS?

3291.text: How did we stop sun cancer? Slip slop slap.

3294.text: How did we stop smoking? Quit.

3297.text: We need something like that to go at the base level

3301.text: the community level. Corporates do have a responsibility,

3304.text: yes, but I think it's just got to grow organically up.

3308.text: I think we've just got to keep talking about it.

3310.text: At every level that we can. Whether it's business to business about the costs

3314.text: that it'll save, or whether it's as an employer

3318.text: I think we just need to keep talking about it to whoever will listen.

3323.text: Can I thank our wonderful panel.

3328.text: John Canning, Megan Kingham, Rachel Clements, Dr Sam Harvey.

3332.text: It's been fantastic to have your expertise and stories in the audience

3336.text: And thank you to the wonderful NSW Mental Health Commission team for pulling this together

3343.text: so professionally and holding it at the Riverside Theatre.

3347.text: Thank you to our venue hosts as well. Thank you.
